Topic.Title: Backroom Deal on CA sales tax??

Message.Msg: It's new ground here. A deal was struck for AMZN to agree to collect very high CA sales tax. This seems very within the realm of possibilities. Of course, giving tax breaks to business is nothing new at all. Walmart often demands and gets a tax break when they build many of their new stores in the past. The only difference here with Amazon is how close and overt it may be to collect "tax" and then pocket a portion straight or get a straight up kickback. That would be a loser in court. They may very well have not thought it through or hidden the kickback well enough. I'm sure Moonbeam's team wouldn't have been smart enough on one side of it.

Message.Title: Amazon forced to collect tax from Sept 15
Message.Msg: We knew this day was coming, so enjoy the free ride while it lasts. The days of skirting the sales tax for most online purchases are numbered for Californians. The Department of Finance certified this week no federal internet tax law exists, opening the door for a new state law to take effect September 15 when out-of-state e-tailers like Amazon and Overstock must start collecting the sales tax, a big annual boost to California coffers.

Topic.Title: downgraded to neutral, on future sales tax hitting margins.

Message.Msg: Yes, but collecting taxes reduces their competitive pricing advantage, which reduces their revenue and growth rate, which squeezes their less than 1% margins. State by state AMZN has been negotiating how to not pay or how to delay paying sales taxes. The upshot is that they eventually agree to pay and barter job creation and fulfillment centers built in that state. Their operations growth in fulfillment centers are more a negative effect of their corporate development legal team on steroids than it is because of e need to have fulfillment centers in 50 states. Instead of having a hub and spoke distribution model, they'll have a hub to more hubs model.

Topic.Title: Bulls--this will end badly for you

Message.Msg: I can't believe it either. As a trader sure these moves are great, but investors have to look at what this company does and has always done. They cut margins to the bones. And all the analysis is that they are finally getting into higher margin businesses. And their solution is to cut prices to 1 cent a GB. I'm not saying they don't have a strategy for massive growth. They just don't have a strategy for massive profits. This company will always make a few billion a year, but it will never be worth its market cap. Because growth without profit is not a business it is a hobby. Maybe at $150 there is a reason to buy in, but at $250 we are way beyond overvalued. This thing could give up 50 points in a week.

Message.Title: New Devices mean NO PRIVACY
Message.Msg: Even if Amazon does come out with something the next few weeks. Here's what it means. It means you will be tracked on everything you do. All ads will pushed your way by what you searched for, or bought. No privacy. So much for that surprise B-Day present you got. Others will know what you bought. You are giving away all of your rights, and you don't even know it. This means everything you do, or what you are doing, will be used against you.

Message.Title: nbc video offering cost?
Message.Msg: This stock goes up without making money based on what? Oh they outbid Netflix for Nbc shows. We all know how netflix is losing money because their content costs went up skyhigh. Since amzn had to pay more that netflix, does anyone think they will make money off streaming video anytime soon? I bet next quarter they show increasing losses from video costs. Add that to losses from warehouse expense and then don't wonder why revenue went up but we lost more money like netflix. Hedge fund managers are acting like 2000 tech gamblers again. I don't care about earnings. It's Vegas. It's hot. It's going up. They obviously don't know how to or want to listen to any kind of discounted cashflow analysis of the stock valuation or they wouldn't be buying at 240 a share. They are beating up best buy but best buy makes more per share than amzn.
